fields.headline: Post-charge rights
fields.bodyText: I welcome the attorney general's comments on post-charge questioning and intercept evidence (Police to be able to question suspects after charge, April 19). The joint committee on human rights recommended in our report last summer that the law be changed to allow post-charge questioning and, with appropriate safeguards, adverse inferences to be drawn from a refusal to answer. As the attorney general acknowledges, this would enhance human-rights protection because it would lessen the pressure for a further extension of the 28-day limit on detention without charge. The joint committee also recommended lifting the ban on the use of intercept evidence in court, as part of a package of measures to facilitate prosecution. The human rights-compatible way to counter the threat from terrorism is to remove unnecessary obstacles to prosecution and return to using the ordinary criminal process. Andrew Dismore MP Chair, joint committee on human rights, House of Commons
